<u>General Conclusions & Deductions from the 
foregoing.<\u>
From what has preceded it will be seen that 
my researches have led me to conclusions in 
regard to the structural connections <s> of the useful <\s>
& functional significance of the corpus callosum 
widely different from those wh: are generally accepted at the 
present day. One great & primary conclusion 
of wh: I am myself thoroughly satisfied is that 
the corpus callosum is not a commissure at 
all. The idea that bilateral action of the 
two hemispheres would be obtained by connecting 
the convolutions of the two hemispheres directly 
is <s>it<\s> I hold an erroneous physiological conclusion,
& I question whether any such arrangement 
exists in the brain at all. The <u>anterior commissure <\u>
is I believe no more a commissure in the ordinary 
acceptation of the term than the corpus callosum 
is. So far as I know the whole of the cerebral 
systemic fibres cross at some point in the cerebrospinal axis. <s>unless there 
there <\s> The motor fibres wh: have already crossed 
in the anterior pyramids <s>The latter <\s> seem to run 
up directly to the motor area of the cortex.
All the other fibres of the cortex, however, cross in 
some part of the brain pons or medulla or cord and 
the destination of the majority of these fibres after 
they have crossed is to become attached to a 
ganglionic centre on the opposite side.
